name: src/Badger/Codecs/Json.js
content:
/**
 * Function to encode JSON
 * @param {Object} data - The data to encode as JSON text
 * @return {String} a JSON encoded string
 * @example
 * encode({ message: 'Hello World' })
 */
export const encode = data => JSON.stringify(data);

/**
 * Function to decode JSON
 * @param {String} text - The JSON text to decode
 * @return {Object|Array} the decoded object or array
 * @example
 * decode("{ message: 'Hello World' }")
 */
export const decode = text => JSON.parse(text);

/**
 * An object containing the JSON `encode` and `decode` functions
 */
export const codec = { encode, decode };

export default codec

name: encode
description: Function to encode JSON

params.name: data
params.description: The data to encode as JSON text

name: decode
description: Function to decode JSON

name: codec
description: An object containing the JSON `encode` and `decode` functions

name: src/Badger/Utils/Debug.js
content:
import { escape, reset } from './Color.js'
import { doNothing } from './Misc.js';

/**
 * Returns a debugging function which is enabled by the first `enabled` argument.
 * If this is `false` then it returns a function which does nothing.  If it is
 * true then it returns a function that forwards all arguments to `console.log`.
 * An optional `prefix` be be specified to prefix each debugging line.  The
 * optional third argument `color` can be used to specify a color for the prefix.
 * @param {Boolean} enabled - is debugging enabled?
 * @param {String} [prefix] - optional prefix for debugging messages
 * @param {String|Object} [color] - a color name or object (see {@link Badger/Utils/Color})
 * @param {String} [color.fg] - foreground color
 * @param {String} [color.bg] - background color
 * @return {Function} a debugging function
 * @example
 * const debug = Debugger(true)
 * @example
 * const debug = Debugger(true, 'Debug > ')
 * @example
 * const debug = Debugger(true, 'Debug > ', 'blue')
 * @example
 * const debug = Debugger(true, 'Debug > ', { bg: 'blue', fg: 'bright yellow' })
 */
export function Debugger(enabled, prefix='', color) {
  return enabled
    ? prefix
      ? (format, ...args) =>
        console.log(
          '%s' + prefix + '%s: ' + format,
          color ? escape(color) : '',
          reset(),
          ...args,
        )
      : console.log.bind(console)
    : doNothing;
}

/**
 * Creates a debugging function via {@link Debugger} and attaches it to the object
 * passed as the first argument as the `debug` function.
 * @param {Object} obj - the object to receive the `debug` function
 * @param {Boolean} enabled - is debugging enabled?
 * @param {String} [prefix] - optional prefix for debugging messages
 * @param {String|Object} [color] - a color name or object (see {@link Badger/Utils/Color})
 * @param {String} [color.fg] - foreground color
 * @param {String} [color.bg] - background color
 * @example
 * const debug = addDebug(myObject, true)
 * @example
 * const debug = addDebug(myObject, true, 'Debug > ')
 * @example
 * const debug = addDebug(myObject, true, 'Debug > ', 'blue')
 * @example
 * const debug = addDebug(myObject, true, 'Debug > ', { bg: 'blue', fg: 'bright yellow' })
 */
export function addDebug(obj, enabled, prefix='', color) {
    obj.debug = Debugger(enabled, prefix, color);
}

name: Debugger
description:
Returns a debugging function which is enabled by the first `enabled` argument.
If this is `false` then it returns a function which does nothing.  If it is
true then it returns a function that forwards all arguments to `console.log`.
An optional `prefix` be be specified to prefix each debugging line.  The
optional third argument `color` can be used to specify a color for the prefix.
examples: const debug = Debugger(true, 'Debug > ', { bg: 'blue', fg: 'bright yellow' })

params.name: color
params.description: a color name or object (see {@link Badger/Utils/Color})

name: addDebug
description:
Creates a debugging function via {@link Debugger} and attaches it to the object
passed as the first argument as the `debug` function.
examples: const debug = addDebug(myObject, true, 'Debug > ', { bg: 'blue', fg: 'bright yellow' })

params.name: obj
params.description: the object to receive the `debug` function

params.name: color
params.description: a color name or object (see {@link Badger/Utils/Color})

name: src/Badger/Utils/Misc.js
isString
description: Determines if a value is a string

return.description: true if `value` is a string or false if not

name: isArray
description: Determines if a value is an array

return.description: true if `value` is an Array or false if not

name: isFunction
description: Determines if a value is a Function

return.description: true if `value` is a Function or false if not

name: isObject
description: Determines if a value is an Object (but not an Array)

return.description: true if `value` is an Object or false if not

name: isUndefined
description: Determines if a value is `undefined`

return.description: true if `value` is `undefined` or false if not

name: isNull
description: Determines if a value is `null`

return.description: true if `value` is `null` or false if not

name: hasValue
description: Determines if a value is defined and not null

name: haveValue
description: Determines if all values are defined and not null

return.description: true if all values are not `undefined` or `null`

name: noValue
description: Determines if a value is undefined or null

name: fail
description: Throws a new Error object

name: rethrow
description: Re-throw an existing Error object

name: doNothing
description: Do nothing.  Nothing at all.

name: src/Badger/Utils/Params.js
requiredParam
description: Assert than a parameter object contains an item with a defined/non-null value

throws.description: if the parameter is not defined or null

name: requiredParams
description: Assert than a parameter object contains all specified item with a defined/non-null value
examples: const [foo, bar] = requiredParams({ foo: 10, bar: 20 }, 'foo bar');

params.name: names
params.description: parameters that must be included, as an Array or whitespace/comma delimited string (see {@link splitList})

throws.description: if any parameter is not defined or null

name: allParams
description: An alias for {@link requiredParams} for people who don't like typing long names (and for symmetry with {@link anyParams}))

name: anyParams
description: Assert than a parameter object contains any of the specified items with a defined/non-null value
examples: const [foo, bar] = anyParams({ foo: 10, wiz: 99 }, 'foo bar');

params.name: names
params.description: parameters of which at least one must be included, as an Array or whitespace/comma delimited string (see {@link splitList})

throws.description: if any parameter is not defined or null

name: src/Badger/Utils/Text.js
splitList
description: Split a comma/whitespace delimited string into an Array

name: joinList
description: Join an Array into a single string
examples: joinList(['one', 'two', 'three'], ', ', ' and ');   // one, two and three

name: joinListAnd
description: Join an Array into a single string using commas for delimiters and ` and ` for the final item

name: joinListOr
description: Join an Array into a single string using commas for delimiters and ` or ` for the final item

name: capitalise
description: Capitalise a string by converting the first character to upper case and other characters to lower case

name: snakeToStudly
description: Convert a snake case string to studly caps

name: snakeToCamel
description: Convert a snake case string to camel case

content:
# badger-js

This is an application toolkit for Javascript projects.  It provides a number of
classes and utility functions to make life easier.

It is loosely based around the [https://github.com/abw/Badger](Badger) toolkit for
Perl.

It was written to help migrate some old Perl projects to Javascript.
name: ./README.md

content:
{
  "name": "badger-js",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "Component based framework and utility modules",
  "type": "module",
  "main": "dist/badger.cjs.js",
  "module": "dist/badger.esm.js",
  "browser": "dist/badger.umd.js",
  "repository": {
    "type": "git",
    "url": "git+https://github.com/abw/badger-js.git"
  },
  "bugs": {
    "url": "https://github.com/abw/badger-js/issues"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "build": "rollup -c",
    "dev": "rollup -c -w",
    "build-docs": "esdoc",
    "serve-docs": "serve docs",
    "test": "ava --serial",
    "pretest": "pnpm run build"
  },
  "keywords": [
    "badger",
    "project",
    "framework",
    "utility"
  ],
  "author": "Andy Wardley",
  "license": "MIT",
  "devDependencies": {
    "@itsjamie/esdoc-cli": "^0.5.0",
    "@itsjamie/esdoc-core": "^0.5.0",
    "@itsjamie/esdoc-standard-plugin": "^0.5.0",
    "@rollup/plugin-commonjs": "^11.0.1",
    "@rollup/plugin-node-resolve": "^7.1.3",
    "ava": "^4.3.0",
    "rollup": "^1.29.0"
  },
  "files": [
    "dist"
  ],
  "dependencies": {
    "fs-extra": "^10.1.0",
    "js-yaml": "^4.1.0"
  }
}
name: package.json

content:
# badger

This is the manual for `badger`

## Overview

`badger` is a collection of utility modules for Javascript.

## Installation

Install `badger` using your favourite package manager.

### npm

    npm install @abw/badger

### pnpm

    pnpm install @abw/badger

### yarn

    yarn add @abw/badger
